member.name: M:SimplexNoise.Noise.Generate(System.Single)
member.summary: 1D simplex noise

member.name: M:SimplexNoise.Noise.Generate(System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: 2D simplex noise

members.member: The noise used for generating Voronoi seeds
Size of the Voronoi cells (avg X/Y distance between the seeds). Expected to be at least 2.
The amount that the cell seeds may be offset from the grid. Expected to be at least 1 and less than m_CellSize.
The constant amount that the cell seeds of every odd row will be offset from the grid. This allows us to have non-rectangular grids. Expected to be between -m_CellSize and +m_CellSize.
The X coordinate of the currently cached cell neighborhood
The Z coordinate of the currently cached cell neighborhood
The seeds of cells around m_CurrentCellX, m_CurrentCellZ, X-coords
The seeds of cells around m_CurrentCellX, m_CurrentCellZ, X-coords
Sets both the cell size and jitter size used for generating the Voronoi seeds.
Sets the jitter size. Clamps it to current cell size.
Sets the offset that is added to each odd row of cells. This offset makes the voronoi cells align to a non-grid. Clamps the value to [-m_CellSize, +m_CellSize].
Returns the value in the cell into which the specified point lies.
Returns the value in the cell into which the specified point lies, and the distance to the nearest Voronoi seed.
Returns the value in the cell into which the specified point lies, and the distances to the 2 nearest Voronoi seeds. Uses a cache.
Finds the nearest and second nearest seeds, returns their coords.
Updates the cached cell seeds to match the specified cell. Noop if cell pos already matches. Updates m_SeedX and m_SeedZ.

member.name: T:System.Threading.CancellationToken
member.summary: Propagates notification that operations should be canceled.

remarks.para: A may be created directly in an unchangeable canceled or non-canceled state using the CancellationToken's constructors. However, to have a CancellationToken that can change from a non-canceled to a canceled state, CancellationTokenSource must be used. CancellationTokenSource exposes the associated CancellationToken that may be canceled by the source through its Token property.
Once canceled, a token may not transition to a non-canceled state, and a token whose is false will never change to one that can be canceled.
All members of this struct are thread-safe and may be used concurrently from multiple threads.

member.name: P:System.Threading.CancellationToken.None
member.summary: Returns an empty CancellationToken value.
member.remarks: The value returned by this property will be non-cancelable by default.

member.name: P:System.Threading.CancellationToken.IsCancellationRequested
member.summary: Gets whether cancellation has been requested for this token.
member.value: Whether cancellation has been requested for this token.

remarks.para: This property indicates whether cancellation has been requested for this token, either through the token initially being construted in a canceled state, or through calling Cancel on the token's associated .

If this property is true, it only guarantees that cancellation has been requested. It does not guarantee that every registered handler has finished executing, nor that cancellation requests have finished propagating to all registered handlers. Additional synchronization may be required, particularly in situations where related objects are being canceled concurrently.

member.name: P:System.Threading.CancellationToken.CanBeCanceled
member.summary: Gets whether this token is capable of being in the canceled state.
member.remarks: If CanBeCanceled returns false, it is guaranteed that the token will never transition into a canceled state, meaning that will never return true.

member.name: P:System.Threading.CancellationToken.WaitHandle
member.summary: Gets a that is signaled when the token is canceled.
member.remarks: Accessing this property causes a WaitHandle to be instantiated. It is preferable to only use this property when necessary, and to then dispose the associated instance at the earliest opportunity (disposing the source will dispose of this allocated handle). The handle should not be closed or disposed directly.
member.exception: The associated CancellationTokenSource has been disposed.

member.name: M:System.Threading.CancellationToken.#ctor(System.Threading.CancellationTokenSource)
member.summary: Internal constructor only a CancellationTokenSource should create a CancellationToken

member.name: M:System.Threading.CancellationToken.#ctor(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Initializes the CancellationToken.
member.param: The canceled state for the token.

member.name: M:System.Threading.CancellationToken.Register(System.Action)
member.summary: Registers a delegate that will be called when this CancellationToken is canceled.

remarks.para: If this token is already in the canceled state, the delegate will be run immediately and synchronously. Any exception the delegate generates will be propagated out of this method call.
The current ExecutionContext, if one exists, will be captured along with the delegate and will be used when executing it.

member.param: The delegate to be executed when the CancellationToken is canceled.
member.returns: The instance that can be used to deregister the callback.

member.name: M:System.Threading.CancellationToken.Register(System.Action{System.Object},System.Object)

remarks.para: If this token is already in the canceled state, the delegate will be run immediately and synchronously. Any exception the delegate generates will be propagated out of this method call.

member.param: The delegate to be executed when the CancellationToken is canceled.

member.returns: The instance that can be used to deregister the callback.

member.name: T:System.Threading.CancellationTokenSource
member.summary: Signals to a that it should be canceled.

remarks.para: is used to instantiate a (via the source's Token property) that can be handed to operations that wish to be notified of cancellation or that can be used to register asynchronous operations for cancellation. That token may have cancellation requested by calling to the source's Cancel method.
All members of this class, except Dispose, are thread-safe and may be used concurrently from multiple threads.

members.member: The ID of the thread currently executing the main body of CTS.Cancel() this helps us to know if a call to ctr.Dispose() is running 'within' a cancellation callback. This is updated as we move between the main thread calling cts.Cancel() and any syncContexts that are used to actually run the callbacks.

member.name: P:System.Threading.CancellationTokenSource.IsCancellationRequested
member.summary: Gets whether cancellation has been requested for this CancellationTokenSource.
member.value: Whether cancellation has been requested for this CancellationTokenSource.

remarks.para: This property indicates whether cancellation has been requested for this token source, such as due to a call to its Cancel method.

If this property returns true, it only guarantees that cancellation has been requested. It does not guarantee that every handler registered with the corresponding token has finished executing, nor that cancellation requests have finished propagating to all registered handlers. Additional synchronization may be required, particularly in situations where related objects are being canceled concurrently.

member.summary: A simple helper to determine whether cancellation has finished.

member.name: M:System.Threading.CancellationTokenSource.Cancel
member.summary: Communicates a request for cancellation.

remarks.para: The associated will be notified of the cancellation and will transition to a state where IsCancellationRequested returns true. Any callbacks or cancelable operations registered with the will be executed.

Cancelable operations and callbacks registered with the token should not throw exceptions. However, this overload of Cancel will aggregate any exceptions thrown into a , such that one callback throwing an exception will not prevent other registered callbacks from being executed.
The that was captured when each callback was registered will be reestablished when the callback is invoked.

member.exception: An aggregate exception containing all the exceptions thrown by the registered callbacks on the associated .

member.name: M:System.Threading.CancellationTokenSource.Cancel(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Communicates a request for cancellation.

remarks.para: The associated will be notified of the cancellation and will transition to a state where IsCancellationRequested returns true. Any callbacks or cancelable operations registered with the will be executed.

Cancelable operations and callbacks registered with the token should not throw exceptions. If is true, an exception will immediately propagate out of the call to Cancel, preventing the remaining callbacks and cancelable operations from being processed. If is false, this overload will aggregate any exceptions thrown into a , such that one callback throwing an exception will not prevent other registered callbacks from being executed.
The that was captured when each callback was registered will be reestablished when the callback is invoked.

member.param: Specifies whether exceptions should immediately propagate.
member.exception: An aggregate exception containing all the exceptions thrown by the registered callbacks on the associated .

member.name: M:System.Threading.CancellationTokenSource.CancelAfter(System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: Schedules a Cancel operation on this .
member.param: The time span to wait before canceling this .
member.exception: The exception thrown when this has been disposed.
The exception thrown when is less than -1 or greater than Int32.MaxValue.

remarks.para: The countdown for the delay starts during this call. When the delay expires, this is canceled, if it has not been canceled already.
Subsequent calls to CancelAfter will reset the delay for this , if it has not been canceled already.

member.name: M:System.Threading.CancellationTokenSource.CancelAfter(System.Int32)
member.summary: Schedules a Cancel operation on this .
member.param: The time span to wait before canceling this .
member.exception: The exception thrown when this has been disposed.
The exception thrown when is less than -1.

remarks.para: The countdown for the millisecondsDelay starts during this call. When the millisecondsDelay expires, this is canceled, if it has not been canceled already.
Subsequent calls to CancelAfter will reset the millisecondsDelay for this , if it has not been canceled already.

member.name: T:System.Threading.SpinWait
member.summary: Provides support for spin-based waiting.

remarks.para: encapsulates common spinning logic. On single-processor machines, yields are always used instead of busy waits, and on computers with Intelâ„¢ processors employing Hyper-Threadingâ„¢ technology, it helps to prevent hardware thread starvation. SpinWait encapsulates a good mixture of spinning and true yielding.

is a value type, which means that low-level code can utilize SpinWait without fear of unnecessary allocation overheads. SpinWait is not generally useful for ordinary applications. In most cases, you should use the synchronization classes provided by the .NET Framework, such as . For most purposes where spin waiting is required, however, the type should be preferred over the method.

While SpinWait is designed to be used in concurrent applications, it is not designed to be used from multiple threads concurrently. SpinWait's members are not thread-safe. If multiple threads must spin, each should use its own instance of SpinWait.

member.name: P:System.Threading.SpinWait.Count

member.summary: Gets whether the next call to will yield the processor, triggering a forced context switch.
member.value: Whether the next call to will yield the processor, triggering a forced context switch.
member.remarks: On a single-CPU machine, always yields the processor. On machines with multiple CPUs, may yield after an unspecified number of calls.

member.name: M:System.Threading.SpinWait.SpinOnce
member.summary: Performs a single spin.
member.remarks: This is typically called in a loop, and may change in behavior based on the number of times a has been called thus far on this instance.

member.summary: Resets the spin counter.
member.remarks: This makes and behave as though no calls to had been issued on this instance. If a instance is reused many times, it may be useful to reset it to avoid yielding too soon.

summary.para: Extends to support simple thread-synchronisation for read/write to the buffer by allowing callers to acquire and release read/write locks.
All buffer read/write operations have been overloaded to first perform a using the and respectively.
By default all read/write operations will not block, it is necessary to first acquire locks through calls to and as appropriate, with corresponding calls to and to release the locks.

member.name: P:SharedMemory.BufferWithLocks.WriteWaitEvent
member.summary: An event handle used for blocking write operations.

member.name: P:SharedMemory.BufferWithLocks.ReadWaitEvent
member.summary: An event handle used for blocking read operations.

member.name: M:SharedMemory.BufferWithLocks.#ctor(System.String,System.Int64,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Create a new instance with the specified name and buffer size.
member.param: The name of the shared memory
The buffer size in bytes.
Whether or not the current instance owns the shared memory. If true a new shared memory will be created and initialised otherwise an existing one is opened.

member.name: P:SharedMemory.BufferWithLocks.ReadWriteTimeout
member.summary: The Read/Write operation timeout in milliseconds (to prevent deadlocks). Defaults to 100ms and must be larger than -1. If a Read or Write operation's WaitEvent does not complete within this timeframe a will be thrown. If using AcquireReadLock/ReleaseReadLock and AcquireWriteLock/ReleaseWriteLock correctly this timeout will never occur.

member.name: M:SharedMemory.BufferWithLocks.AcquireReadLock(System.Int32)
member.summary: Blocks the current thread until it is able to acquire a read lock. If successful all subsequent writes will be blocked until after a call to .
member.param: The number of milliseconds to wait, or (-1) to wait indefinitely.
member.returns: true if the read lock was able to be acquired, otherwise false.
member.exception: is a negative number other than -1, which represents an infinite time-out.
member.remarks: If is (-1), then attempting to acquire a read lock after acquiring a write lock on the same thread will result in a deadlock.

member.name: M:SharedMemory.BufferWithLocks.ReleaseReadLock
member.summary: Releases the current read lock, allowing all blocked writes to continue.

member.name: M:SharedMemory.BufferWithLocks.AcquireWriteLock(System.Int32)
member.summary: Blocks the current thread until it is able to acquire a write lock. If successful all subsequent reads will be blocked until after a call to .
member.param: The number of milliseconds to wait, or System.Threading.Timeout.Infinite (-1) to wait indefinitely.
member.returns: true if the write lock was able to be acquired, otherwise false.
member.exception: is a negative number other than -1, which represents an infinite time-out.
member.remarks: If is (-1), then attempting to acquire a write lock after acquiring a read lock on the same thread will result in a deadlock.

member.name: M:SharedMemory.BufferWithLocks.ReleaseWriteLock
member.summary: Releases the current write lock, allowing all blocked reads to continue.

member.name: M:SharedMemory.BufferWithLocks.WriteWait
member.summary: Prevents write operations from deadlocking by throwing a TimeoutException if the WriteWaitEvent is not available within milliseconds

member.name: M:SharedMemory.CircularBuffer.#ctor(System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates and opens a new instance with the specified name, node count and buffer size per node.
member.param: The name of the shared memory to be created
The number of nodes within the circular linked-list (minimum of 2)

The buffer size per node in bytes. The total shared memory size will be Marshal.SizeOf(SharedMemory.SharedHeader) + Marshal.SizeOf(CircularBuffer.NodeHeader) + (Marshal.SizeOf(CircularBuffer.Node) * nodeCount) + (bufferSize * nodeCount)

remarks.para: The maximum total shared memory size is dependent upon the system and current memory fragmentation.

The shared memory layout on 32-bit and 64-bit architectures is:
| Header | NodeHeader | Node[0] | ... | Node[N-1] | buffer[0] | ... | buffer[N-1] |
| 16-bytes | 24-bytes | 32-bytes * N | NodeBufferSize * N |
|------------------------------BufferSize-----------------------------------|
|-----------------------------------------SharedMemorySize---------------------------------------|

For a 32-byte structure with 1 million iterations:
The method performs approx. 20x faster than (8ms vs 160ms), and about 1.6x slower than the non-generic equivalent (8ms vs 5ms)
The method performs approx. 8x faster than (4ms vs 34ms).

member.name: M:SharedMemory.SharedBuffer.#ctor(System.String,System.Int64,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Create a new instance with the specified name and buffer size
member.param: The name of the shared memory
The buffer size in bytes. The total shared memory size will be Marshal.SizeOf(SharedMemory.SharedHeader) + bufferSize
Whether or not the current instance owns the shared memory. If true a new shared memory will be created and initialised otherwise an existing one is opened.

remarks.para: The maximum total shared memory size is dependent upon the system and current memory fragmentation.

The shared memory layout on 32-bit and 64-bit is:
| Header | Buffer |
| 16-bytes | bufferSize |

member.name: M:SharedMemory.SharedBuffer.Open
member.summary: Creates a new or opens an existing shared memory buffer with the name of depending on the value of .
member.returns: True if the memory was successfully mapped
member.remarks: If is true then the shared memory buffer will be created, opening will fail in this case if the shared memory already exists. Otherwise if IsOwnerOfSharedMemory is false then the shared memory buffer will be opened, which will fail if it doesn't already exist.
member.exception: If trying to create a new shared memory buffer with a duplicate name as buffer owner.
If trying to open a new shared memory buffer that does not exist as a consumer of existing buffer.
If trying to create a new shared memory buffer with a size larger than the logical addressable space.

member.summary: This method is a safe way to fire an event in a multithreaded process. Since there is a tiny chance that the event becomes null after the null check but before the invocation, we use this extension where the event is passed as an argument. Why is this helpful? MulticastDelagates are immutable, so if you first assign a variable, null check against the variable and invoke through it, you are safe

member.name: T:ScottGarland.BigInteger
member.summary: Represents a integer of abitrary length.

remarks.para: A BigInteger object is immutable like System.String. The object can not be modifed, and new BigInteger objects are created by using the operations of existing BigInteger objects.

Internally a BigInteger object is an array of ? that is represents the digits of the n-place integer. Negative BigIntegers are stored internally as 1's complements, thus every BigInteger object contains 1 or more padding elements to hold the sign.

member.name: T:FullSerializer.fsConverterRegistrar
member.summary: This class allows arbitrary code to easily register global converters. To add a converter, simply declare a new field called "Register_*" that stores the type of converter you would like to add. Alternatively, you can do the same with a method called "Register_*"; just add the converter type to the `Converters` list.

member.name: P:FullSerializer.fsAotCompilationManager.AvailableAotCompilations
member.summary:
Ahead of time compilations that are available. The type maps to the object type the generated converter will serialize/deserialize, and the string is the text content for a converter that will do the serialization.
The generated serializer is completely independent and you don't need to do anything. Simply add the file to your project and it'll get used instead of the reflection based one.

member.name: T:FullSerializer.fsDirectConverter
member.summary: The direct converter is similar to a regular converter, except that it targets specifically only one type. This means that it can be used without performance impact when discovering converters. It is strongly recommended that you derive from fsDirectConverter{TModel}.
member.remarks: Due to the way that direct converters operate, inheritance is *not* supported. Direct converters will only be used with the exact ModelType object.

member.name: T:FullSerializer.fsMemberSerialization
member.summary: Controls how the reflected converter handles member serialization.

member.name: F:FullSerializer.fsMemberSerialization.OptIn
member.summary: Only members with [SerializeField] or [fsProperty] attributes are serialized.

member.name: F:FullSerializer.fsMemberSerialization.OptOut
member.summary: Only members with [NotSerialized] or [fsIgnore] will not be serialized.

member.name: F:FullSerializer.fsMemberSerialization.Default
member.summary: The default member serialization behavior is applied.

member.name: T:FullSerializer.fsObjectAttribute
member.summary: This attribute controls some serialization behavior for a type. See the comments on each of the fields for more information.

member.name: F:FullSerializer.fsObjectAttribute.PreviousModels
member.summary: The previous model that should be used if an old version of this object is encountered. Using this attribute also requires that the type have a public constructor that takes only one parameter, an object instance of the given type. Use of this parameter *requires* that the VersionString parameter is also set.

member.name: F:FullSerializer.fsObjectAttribute.VersionString
member.summary: The version string to use for this model. This should be unique among all prior versions of this model that is supported for importation. If PreviousModel is set, then this attribute must also be set. A good valid example for this is "v1", "v2", "v3", ...

member.name: F:FullSerializer.fsObjectAttribute.MemberSerialization
member.summary: This controls the behavior for member serialization. The default behavior is fsMemberSerialization.Default.

member.name: F:FullSerializer.fsObjectAttribute.Converter
member.summary: Specify a custom converter to use for serialization. The converter type needs to derive from fsBaseConverter. This defaults to null.

member.name: F:FullSerializer.fsObjectAttribute.Processor
member.summary: Specify a custom processor to use during serialization. The processor type needs to derive from fsObjectProcessor and the call to CanProcess is not invoked. This defaults to null.

summary.para: Enables injecting code before/after an object has been serialized. This is most useful if you want to run the default serialization process but apply a pre/post processing step.

Multiple object processors can be active at the same time. When running they are called in a "nested" fashion - if we have processor1 and process2 added to the serializer in that order (p1 then p2), then the execution order will be p1#Before p2#Before /serialization/ p2#After p1#After.

member.name: M:FullSerializer.fsObjectProcessor.CanProcess(System.Type)
member.summary: Is the processor interested in objects of the given type?
member.param: The given type.
member.returns: True if the processor should be applied, false otherwise.

member.summary: Called before serialization.
member.param: The field/property type that is storing the instance.
The type of the instance.

member.summary: Called after serialization.
member.param: The field/property type that is storing the instance.
The type of the instance.
The data that was serialized.

member.name: M:FullSerializer.fsObjectProcessor.OnBeforeDeserialize(System.Type,FullSerializer.fsData@)
member.summary: Called before deserialization.
member.param: The field/property type that is storing the instance.
The data that will be used for deserialization.

member.name: M:FullSerializer.fsObjectProcessor.OnBeforeDeserializeAfterInstanceCreation(System.Type,System.Object,FullSerializer.fsData@)
member.summary: Called before deserialization has begun but *after* the object instance has been created. This will get invoked even if the user passed in an existing instance.
member.remarks: **IMPORTANT**: The actual instance that gets passed here is *not* guaranteed to be an a subtype of storageType, since the value for instance is whatever the active converter returned for CreateInstance() - ie, some converters will return dummy types in CreateInstance() if instance creation cannot be separated from deserialization (ie, KeyValuePair).
member.param: The field/property type that is storing the instance.
The created object instance. No deserialization has been applied to it.
The data that will be used for deserialization.

member.name: M:FullSerializer.fsObjectProcessor.OnAfterDeserialize(System.Type,System.Object)
member.summary: Called after deserialization.
member.param: The field/property type that is storing the instance.
The type of the instance.

member.name: T:FullSerializer.fsResult
member.summary: The result of some sort of operation. A result is either successful or not, but if it is successful then there may be a set of warnings/messages associated with it. These warnings describe the performed error recovery operations.

member.name: F:FullSerializer.fsResult._success
member.summary: Is this result successful?
member.remarks: This is intentionally a `success` state so that when the object is default constructed it defaults to a failure state.

member.name: F:FullSerializer.fsResult._messages
member.summary: The warning or error messages associated with the result. This may be null if there are no messages.

member.name: M:FullSerializer.fsResult.AddMessage(System.String)
member.summary: Adds a new message to this result.

member.name: M:FullSerializer.fsResult.AddMessages(FullSerializer.fsResult)
member.summary: Adds only the messages from the other result into this result, ignoring the success/failure status of the other result.

member.name: M:FullSerializer.fsResult.Merge(FullSerializer.fsResult)
member.summary: Merges the other result into this one. If the other result failed, then this one too will have failed.
member.remarks: Note that you can use += instead of this method so that you don't bury the actual method call that is generating the other fsResult.

member.name: F:FullSerializer.fsResult.Success
member.summary: A successful result.

member.name: M:FullSerializer.fsResult.Warn(System.String)
member.summary: Create a result that is successful but contains the given warning message.

member.name: M:FullSerializer.fsResult.Fail(System.String)
member.summary: Create a result that failed.

member.name: M:FullSerializer.fsResult.op_Addition(FullSerializer.fsResult,FullSerializer.fsResult)
member.summary: Only use this as +=!

member.name: P:FullSerializer.fsResult.Failed
member.summary: Did this result fail? If so, you can see the reasons why in `RawMessages`.

member.name: P:FullSerializer.fsResult.Succeeded
member.summary: Was the result a success? Note that even successful operations may have warning messages (`RawMessages`) associated with them.

member.name: P:FullSerializer.fsResult.HasWarnings
member.summary: Does this result have any warnings? This says nothing about if it failed or succeeded, just if it has warning messages associated with it.

member.name: M:FullSerializer.fsResult.AssertSuccess
member.summary: A simply utility method that will assert that this result is successful. If it is not, then an exception is thrown.

member.name: M:FullSerializer.fsResult.AssertSuccessWithoutWarnings
member.summary: A simple utility method that will assert that this result is successful and that there are no warning messages. This throws an exception if either of those asserts are false.

member.name: P:FullSerializer.fsResult.AsException
member.summary: Utility method to convert the result to an exception. This method is only defined is `Failed` returns true.

member.name: M:FullSerializer.fsSerializer.IsReservedKeyword(System.String)
member.summary: Returns true if the given key is a special keyword that full serializer uses to add additional metadata on top of the emitted JSON.

member.summary: This is an object reference in part of a cyclic graph.

member.name: F:FullSerializer.fsSerializer.Key_ObjectDefinition
member.summary: This is an object definition, as part of a cyclic graph.

member.name: F:FullSerializer.fsSerializer.Key_InstanceType
member.summary: This specifies the actual type of an object (the instance type was different from the field type).

member.name: F:FullSerializer.fsSerializer.Key_Version
member.summary: The version string for the serialized data.

member.name: F:FullSerializer.fsSerializer.Key_Content
member.summary: If we have to add metadata but the original serialized state was not a dictionary, then this will contain the original data.

member.name: M:FullSerializer.fsSerializer.StripDeserializationMetadata(FullSerializer.fsData@)
member.summary: Strips all deserialization metadata from the object, like $type and $content fields.
member.remarks: After making this call, you will *not* be able to deserialize the same object instance. The metadata is strictly necessary for deserialization!

member.name: M:FullSerializer.fsSerializer.ConvertLegacyData(FullSerializer.fsData@)
member.summary: This function converts legacy serialization data into the new format, so that the import process can be unified and ignore the old format.

member.name: M:FullSerializer.fsSerializer.EnsureDictionary(FullSerializer.fsData)
member.summary: Ensures that the data is a dictionary. If it is not, then it is wrapped inside of one.

member.name: T:FullSerializer.fsSerializer.fsLazyCycleDefinitionWriter
member.summary: This manages instance writing so that we do not write unnecessary $id fields. We only need to write out an $id field when there is a corresponding $ref field. This is able to write $id references lazily because the fsData instance is not actually written out to text until we have entirely finished serializing it.

member.summary: The name of the item being read or written This should be filled out by the storage when MustHaveName = true and deserializing

member.summary: Set to indicate that the name provided is that of a field or property and is needed to reset the value later

member.name: F:Serialization.Entry.OwningType
member.summary: The type of the object which owns the item being serialized or null if not directly owned. This will always be set on serialization and deserialization when MustHaveName = true and can be used to look up field and property information. Or you can ignore it if you don't need it

member.name: P:Serialization.Entry.PropertyInfo
member.summary: The property info or null, if the value did not come from a property. You might want to use the to look up attributes attached to the property definition

member.summary: The field info or null, if the value did not come from a field. You might want to use it to look up attributes attached to the field definition

member.name: M:Serialization.IStorage.StartSerializing
member.summary: Starts the serialization process, the serializer should initialize and wait for data

member.name: M:Serialization.IStorage.FinishedSerializing
member.summary: Called when serialization is complete, should return the data or a key encoded as a byte array that will be used to reinitialize the serializer later

member.name: M:Serialization.IStorage.FinishedDeserializing
member.summary: Called when deserialization is complete, so that resources may be released

member.name: M:Serialization.IStorage.StartSerializing(Serialization.Entry,System.Int32)
member.summary: Called when serializing a new object, the Entry parameter may have MustHaveName set when this is true the name must be persisted as is so that the property or field can be set when retrieving the data. If this routine returns TRUE then no further processing is executed and the object is presumed persisted in its entirety
member.returns: Normally FALSE. True if the object is already fully persisted
member.param: The item being serialized

member.name: M:Serialization.IStorage.FinishSerializing(Serialization.Entry)
member.summary: Called when the last information about an object has been written
member.param: The object being written

member.name: M:Serialization.IStorage.StartDeserializing(Serialization.Entry)
member.summary: Called when deserializing an object. If the Entry parameter has MustHaveName set then the routine should return with the Entry parameter updated with the name and the type of the object in StoredType If the storage is capable of fully recreating the object then this routine should return the fully constructed object, and no further processing will occur. Not this does mean that it must handle its own references for previously seen objects This will be called after DeserializeGetName
member.returns: Normally NULL, it may also return a fully depersisted object

member.name: M:Serialization.IStorage.DeserializeGetName(Serialization.Entry)
member.summary: Called to allow the storage to retrieve the name of the item being deserialized All entries must be named before a call to StartDeserializing, this enables the system to fill out the property setter and capture default stored type information before deserialization commences
member.param: The entry whose name should be filled in

member.name: M:Serialization.IStorage.FinishDeserializing(Serialization.Entry)
member.summary: Called when an object has deserialization complete

member.name: T:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Checksums.Adler32
member.summary:
Computes Adler32 checksum for a stream of data. An Adler32 checksum is not as reliable as a CRC32 checksum, but a lot faster to compute.
The specification for Adler32 may be found in RFC 1950. ZLIB Compressed Data Format Specification version 3.3)
From that document:
"ADLER32 (Adler-32 checksum) This contains a checksum value of the uncompressed data (excluding any dictionary data) computed according to Adler-32 algorithm. This algorithm is a 32-bit extension and improvement of the Fletcher algorithm, used in the ITU-T X.224 / ISO 8073 standard.
Adler-32 is composed of two sums accumulated per byte: s1 is the sum of all bytes, s2 is the sum of all s1 values. Both sums are done modulo 65521. s1 is initialized to 1, s2 to zero. The Adler-32 checksum is stored as s2*65536 + s1 in most- significant-byte first (network) order."
"8.2. The Adler-32 algorithm
The Adler-32 algorithm is much faster than the CRC32 algorithm yet still provides an extremely low probability of undetected errors.
The modulo on unsigned long accumulators can be delayed for 5552 bytes, so the modulo operation time is negligible. If the bytes are a, b, c, the second sum is 3a + 2b + c + 3, and so is position and order sensitive, unlike the first sum, which is just a checksum. That 65521 is prime is important to avoid a possible large class of two-byte errors that leave the check unchanged. (The Fletcher checksum uses 255, which is not prime and which also makes the Fletcher check insensitive to single byte changes 0 - 255.)
The sum s1 is initialized to 1 instead of zero to make the length of the sequence part of s2, so that the length does not have to be checked separately. (Any sequence of zeroes has a Fletcher checksum of zero.)"

member.name: T:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Checksums.Crc32
member.summary:
Generate a table for a byte-wise 32-bit CRC calculation on the polynomial: x^32+x^26+x^23+x^22+x^16+x^12+x^11+x^10+x^8+x^7+x^5+x^4+x^2+x+1.
Polynomials over GF(2) are represented in binary, one bit per coefficient, with the lowest powers in the most significant bit. Then adding polynomials is just exclusive-or, and multiplying a polynomial by x is a right shift by one. If we call the above polynomial p, and represent a byte as the polynomial q, also with the lowest power in the most significant bit (so the byte 0xb1 is the polynomial x^7+x^3+x+1), then the CRC is (q*x^32) mod p, where a mod b means the remainder after dividing a by b.
This calculation is done using the shift-register method of multiplying and taking the remainder. The register is initialized to zero, and for each incoming bit, x^32 is added mod p to the register if the bit is a one (where x^32 mod p is p+x^32 = x^26+...+1), and the register is multiplied mod p by x (which is shifting right by one and adding x^32 mod p if the bit shifted out is a one). We start with the highest power (least significant bit) of q and repeat for all eight bits of q.
The table is simply the CRC of all possible eight bit values. This is all the information needed to generate CRC's on data a byte at a time for all combinations of CRC register values and incoming bytes.

member.name: T:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Core.NameFilter
member.summary: NameFilter is a string matching class which allows for both positive and negative matching. A filter is a sequence of independant regular expressions separated by semi-colons ';'. To include a semi-colon it may be quoted as in \;. Each expression can be prefixed by a plus '+' sign or a minus '-' sign to denote the expression is intended to include or exclude names. If neither a plus or minus sign is found include is the default. A given name is tested for inclusion before checking exclusions. Only names matching an include spec and not matching an exclude spec are deemed to match the filter. An empty filter matches any name.
member.example: The following expression includes all name ending in '.dat' with the exception of 'dummy.dat' "+\.dat$;-^dummy\.dat$"

member.name: T:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.LZW.LzwInputStream
member.summary:
This filter stream is used to decompress a LZW format stream. Specifically, a stream that uses the LZC compression method. This file format is usually associated with the .Z file extension.
See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compress See http://wiki.wxwidgets.org/Development:_Z_File_Format
The file header consists of 3 (or optionally 4) bytes. The first two bytes contain the magic marker "0x1f 0x9d", followed by a byte of flags.
Based on Java code by Ronald Tschalar, which in turn was based on the unlzw.c code in the gzip package.

member.name: T:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Tar.TarArchive
member.summary:
The TarArchive class implements the concept of a 'Tape Archive'. A tar archive is a series of entries, each of which represents a file system object. Each entry in the archive consists of a header block followed by 0 or more data blocks. Directory entries consist only of the header block, and are followed by entries for the directory's contents. File entries consist of a header followed by the number of blocks needed to contain the file's contents. All entries are written on block boundaries. Blocks are 512 bytes long.
TarArchives are instantiated in either read or write mode, based upon whether they are instantiated with an InputStream or an OutputStream. Once instantiated TarArchives read/write mode can not be changed.
There is currently no support for random access to tar archives. However, it seems that subclassing TarArchive, and using the TarBuffer.CurrentRecord and TarBuffer.CurrentBlock properties, this would be rather trivial.

The translation converts the local operating system's concept of line ends into the UNIX line end, '\n', which is the defacto standard for a TAR archive. This makes text files compatible with UNIX.

member.name: T:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Tar.TarBuffer
member.summary:
The TarBuffer class implements the tar archive concept of a buffered input stream. This concept goes back to the days of blocked tape drives and special io devices. In the C# universe, the only real function that this class performs is to ensure that files have the correct "record" size, or other tars will complain.
You should never have a need to access this class directly. TarBuffers are created by Tar IO Streams.

member.name: T:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Tar.TarEntry
member.summary:
This class represents an entry in a Tar archive. It consists of the entry's header, as well as the entry's File. Entries can be instantiated in one of three ways, depending on how they are to be used.
TarEntries that are created from the header bytes read from an archive are instantiated with the TarEntry( byte[] ) constructor. These entries will be used when extracting from or listing the contents of an archive. These entries have their header filled in using the header bytes. They also set the File to null, since they reference an archive entry not a file.
TarEntries that are created from files that are to be written into an archive are instantiated with the CreateEntryFromFile(string) pseudo constructor. These entries have their header filled in using the File's information. They also keep a reference to the File for convenience when writing entries.
Finally, TarEntries can be constructed from nothing but a name. This allows the programmer to construct the entry by hand, for instance when only an InputStream is available for writing to the archive, and the header information is constructed from other information. In this case the header fields are set to defaults and the File is set to null.

member.summary: Get the available data that can be read from the current entry in the archive. This does not indicate how much data is left in the entire archive, only in the current entry. This value is determined from the entry's size header field and the amount of data already read from the current entry.
member.returns: The number of available bytes for the current entry.

member.summary: Skip bytes in the input buffer. This skips bytes in the current entry's data, not the entire archive, and will stop at the end of the current entry's data if the number to skip extends beyond that point.
member.param: The number of bytes to skip.

member.summary: Return a value of true if marking is supported; false otherwise.
member.remarks: Currently marking is not supported, the return value is always false.

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Tar.TarInputStream.Mark(System.Int32)
member.summary: Since we do not support marking just yet, we do nothing.
member.param: The limit to mark.

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Tar.TarInputStream.Reset
member.summary: Since we do not support marking just yet, we do nothing.

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Tar.TarInputStream.GetNextEntry
member.summary: Get the next entry in this tar archive. This will skip over any remaining data in the current entry, if there is one, and place the input stream at the header of the next entry, and read the header and instantiate a new TarEntry from the header bytes and return that entry. If there are no more entries in the archive, null will be returned to indicate that the end of the archive has been reached.
member.returns: The next TarEntry in the archive, or null.

members.member:
The TarOutputStream writes a UNIX tar archive as an OutputStream. Methods are provided to put entries, and then write their contents by writing to this stream using write().

member.summary: Get a value indicating wether an entry is open, requiring more data to be written.

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Tar.TarOutputStream.PutNextEntry(ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Tar.TarEntry)
member.summary: Put an entry on the output stream. This writes the entry's header and positions the output stream for writing the contents of the entry. Once this method is called, the stream is ready for calls to write() to write the entry's contents. Once the contents are written, closeEntry() MUST be called to ensure that all buffered data is completely written to the output stream.
member.param: The TarEntry to be written to the archive.

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Tar.TarOutputStream.CloseEntry
member.summary: Close an entry. This method MUST be called for all file entries that contain data. The reason is that we must buffer data written to the stream in order to satisfy the buffer's block based writes. Thus, there may be data fragments still being assembled that must be written to the output stream before this entry is closed and the next entry written.

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Tar.TarOutputStream.WriteByte(System.Byte)
member.summary: Writes a byte to the current tar archive entry. This method simply calls Write(byte[], int, int).
member.param: The byte to be written.

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Tar.TarOutputStream.Write(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Writes bytes to the current tar archive entry. This method is aware of the current entry and will throw an exception if you attempt to write bytes past the length specified for the current entry. The method is also (painfully) aware of the record buffering required by TarBuffer, and manages buffers that are not a multiple of recordsize in length, including assembling records from small buffers.
member.param: The buffer to write to the archive.
The offset in the buffer from which to get bytes.
The number of bytes to write.

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Tar.TarOutputStream.WriteEofBlock
member.summary: Write an EOF (end of archive) block to the tar archive. An EOF block consists of all zeros.

member.name: T:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Deflater
member.summary:
This is the Deflater class. The deflater class compresses input with the deflate algorithm described in RFC 1951. It has several compression levels and three different strategies described below.
This class is not thread safe. This is inherent in the API, due to the split of deflate and setInput.
author of the original java version : Jochen Hoenicke

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Deflater.BEST_COMPRESSION
member.summary: The best and slowest compression level. This tries to find very long and distant string repetitions.

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Deflater.BEST_SPEED
member.summary: The worst but fastest compression level.

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Deflater.DEFAULT_COMPRESSION
member.summary: The default compression level.

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Deflater.NO_COMPRESSION
member.summary: This level won't compress at all but output uncompressed blocks.

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Deflater.DEFLATED
member.summary: The compression method. This is the only method supported so far. There is no need to use this constant at all.

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Deflater.#ctor
member.summary: Creates a new deflater with default compression level.

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Deflater.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates a new deflater with given compression level.
member.param: the compression level, a value between NO_COMPRESSION and BEST_COMPRESSION, or DEFAULT_COMPRESSION.
member.exception: if lvl is out of range.

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Deflater.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates a new deflater with given compression level.
member.param: the compression level, a value between NO_COMPRESSION and BEST_COMPRESSION.
true, if we should suppress the Zlib/RFC1950 header at the beginning and the adler checksum at the end of the output. This is useful for the GZIP/PKZIP formats.
member.exception: if lvl is out of range.

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Deflater.Reset
member.summary: Resets the deflater. The deflater acts afterwards as if it was just created with the same compression level and strategy as it had before.

member.name: P:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Deflater.Adler
member.summary: Gets the current adler checksum of the data that was processed so far.

member.name: P:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Deflater.TotalIn
member.summary: Gets the number of input bytes processed so far.

member.name: P:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Deflater.TotalOut
member.summary: Gets the number of output bytes so far.

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Deflater.Flush
member.summary: Flushes the current input block. Further calls to deflate() will produce enough output to inflate everything in the current input block. This is not part of Sun's JDK so I have made it package private. It is used by DeflaterOutputStream to implement flush().

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Deflater.Finish
member.summary: Finishes the deflater with the current input block. It is an error to give more input after this method was called. This method must be called to force all bytes to be flushed.

member.name: P:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Deflater.IsFinished
member.summary: Returns true if the stream was finished and no more output bytes are available.

member.name: P:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Deflater.IsNeedingInput
member.summary: Returns true, if the input buffer is empty. You should then call setInput(). NOTE: This method can also return true when the stream was finished.

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Deflater.SetInput(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Sets the data which should be compressed next. This should be only called when needsInput indicates that more input is needed. If you call setInput when needsInput() returns false, the previous input that is still pending will be thrown away. The given byte array should not be changed, before needsInput() returns true again. This call is equivalent to setInput(input, 0, input.length).
member.param: the buffer containing the input data.
member.exception: if the buffer was finished() or ended().

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Deflater.SetInput(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Sets the data which should be compressed next. This should be only called when needsInput indicates that more input is needed. The given byte array should not be changed, before needsInput() returns true again.
member.param: the buffer containing the input data.
the start of the data.
the number of data bytes of input.
member.exception: if the buffer was Finish()ed or if previous input is still pending.

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Deflater.SetLevel(System.Int32)
member.summary: Sets the compression level. There is no guarantee of the exact position of the change, but if you call this when needsInput is true the change of compression level will occur somewhere near before the end of the so far given input.
member.param: the new compression level.

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Deflater.GetLevel
member.summary: Get current compression level
member.returns: Returns the current compression level

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Deflater.SetStrategy(ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.DeflateStrategy)
member.summary: Sets the compression strategy. Strategy is one of DEFAULT_STRATEGY, HUFFMAN_ONLY and FILTERED. For the exact position where the strategy is changed, the same as for SetLevel() applies.
member.param: The new compression strategy.

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Deflater.Deflate(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Deflates the current input block with to the given array.
member.param: The buffer where compressed data is stored
member.returns: The number of compressed bytes added to the output, or 0 if either IsNeedingInput() or IsFinished returns true or length is zero.

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Deflater.Deflate(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Deflates the current input block to the given array.
member.param: Buffer to store the compressed data.
Offset into the output array.
The maximum number of bytes that may be stored.
member.returns: The number of compressed bytes added to the output, or 0 if either needsInput() or finished() returns true or length is zero.
member.exception: If offset or length don't match the array length.

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Deflater.SetDictionary(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Sets the dictionary which should be used in the deflate process. This call is equivalent to setDictionary(dict, 0, dict.Length).
member.param: the dictionary.
member.exception: if SetInput () or Deflate () were already called or another dictionary was already set.

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Deflater.SetDictionary(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Sets the dictionary which should be used in the deflate process. The dictionary is a byte array containing strings that are likely to occur in the data which should be compressed. The dictionary is not stored in the compressed output, only a checksum. To decompress the output you need to supply the same dictionary again.
member.param: The dictionary data
The index where dictionary information commences.
The number of bytes in the dictionary.
member.exception: If SetInput () or Deflate() were already called or another dictionary was already set.

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.DeflaterEngine.head
member.summary: Hashtable, hashing three characters to an index for window, so that window[index]..window[index+2] have this hash code. Note that the array should really be unsigned short, so you need to and the values with 0xffff.

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.DeflaterEngine.prev
member.summary: prev[index & WMASK] points to the previous index that has the same hash code as the string starting at index. This way entries with the same hash code are in a linked list. Note that the array should really be unsigned short, so you need to and the values with 0xffff.

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.DeflaterEngine.lookahead
member.summary: lookahead is the number of characters starting at strstart in window that are valid. So window[strstart] until window[strstart+lookahead-1] are valid characters.

member.name: F:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.DeflaterEngine.window
member.summary: This array contains the part of the uncompressed stream that is of relevance. The current character is indexed by strstart.

This class is not thread safe. This is inherent in the API, due to the split of Deflate and SetInput.

member.name: T:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Inflater
member.summary:
Inflater is used to decompress data that has been compressed according to the "deflate" standard described in rfc1951.
By default Zlib (rfc1950) headers and footers are expected in the input. You can use constructor public Inflater(bool noHeader) passing true if there is no Zlib header information
The usage is as following. First you have to set some input with SetInput(), then Inflate() it. If inflate doesn't inflate any bytes there may be three reasons:
IsNeedingInput() returns true because the input buffer is empty. You have to provide more input with SetInput(). NOTE: IsNeedingInput() also returns true when, the stream is finished.
IsNeedingDictionary() returns true, you have to provide a preset dictionary with SetDictionary().
IsFinished returns true, the inflater has finished.
Once the first output byte is produced, a dictionary will not be needed at a later stage.
author of the original java version : John Leuner, Jochen Hoenicke

member.summary: Extra bits for distance codes

member.name: T:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Streams.InflaterInputStream
member.summary:
This filter stream is used to decompress data compressed using the "deflate" format. The "deflate" format is described in RFC 1951.
This stream may form the basis for other decompression filters, such as the GZipInputStream.
Author of the original java version : John Leuner.

member.name: T:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Streams.StreamManipulator
member.summary:
This class allows us to retrieve a specified number of bits from the input buffer, as well as copy big byte blocks.
It uses an int buffer to store up to 31 bits for direct manipulation. This guarantees that we can get at least 16 bits, but we only need at most 15, so this is all safe.
There are some optimizations in this class, for example, you must never peek more than 8 bits more than needed, and you must first peek bits before you may drop them. This is not a general purpose class but optimized for the behaviour of the Inflater.
authors of the original java version : John Leuner, Jochen Hoenicke

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Streams.StreamManipulator.#ctor
member.summary: Constructs a default StreamManipulator with all buffers empty

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Streams.StreamManipulator.PeekBits(System.Int32)
member.summary: Get the next sequence of bits but don't increase input pointer. bitCount must be less or equal 16 and if this call succeeds, you must drop at least n - 8 bits in the next call.
member.param: The number of bits to peek.
member.returns: the value of the bits, or -1 if not enough bits available. */

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Streams.StreamManipulator.DropBits(System.Int32)
member.summary: Drops the next n bits from the input. You should have called PeekBits with a bigger or equal n before, to make sure that enough bits are in the bit buffer.
member.param: The number of bits to drop.

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.Compression.Streams.StreamManipulator.GetBits(System.Int32)
member.summary: Gets the next n bits and increases input pointer. This is equivalent to followed by , except for correct error handling.
member.param: The number of bits to retrieve.
member.returns: the value of the bits, or -1 if not enough bits available.

member.summary: Gets the number of bits available in the bit buffer. This must be only called when a previous PeekBits() returned -1.

member.summary: Gets the number of bytes available.

member.remarks: The default value is dynamic which is not backwards compatible with old programs and can cause problems with XP's built in compression which cant read Zip64 archives. However it does avoid the situation were a large file is added and cannot be completed correctly. NOTE: Setting the size for entries before they are added is the best solution! By default the EntryFactory used by FastZip will set fhe file size.

member.name: T:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.ZipEntry
member.summary:
This class represents an entry in a zip archive. This can be a file or a directory ZipFile and ZipInputStream will give you instances of this class as information about the members in an archive. ZipOutputStream uses an instance of this class when creating an entry in a Zip file.
Author of the original java version : Jochen Hoenicke

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.ZipEntry.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Creates a zip entry with the given name.
member.param: The name for this entry. Can include directory components. The convention for names is 'unix' style paths with relative names only. There are with no device names and path elements are separated by '/' characters.

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.ZipEntry.#ctor(System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates a zip entry with the given name and version required to extract
member.param: The name for this entry. Can include directory components. The convention for names is 'unix' style paths with no device names and path elements separated by '/' characters. This is not enforced see CleanName on how to ensure names are valid if this is desired.
The minimum 'feature version' required this entry

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.ZipEntry.#ctor(System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32,ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.CompressionMethod)
member.summary: Initializes an entry with the given name and made by information
member.param: Name for this entry
Version and HostSystem Information
Minimum required zip feature version required to extract this entry
Compression method for this entry.
member.remarks: This constructor is used by the ZipFile class when reading from the central header It is not generally useful, use the constructor specifying the name only.

member.name: P:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.ZipEntry.CryptoCheckValue
member.summary: Value used during password checking for PKZIP 2.0 / 'classic' encryption.

member.name: P:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.ZipEntry.Flags
member.summary: Get/Set general purpose bit flag for entry
member.remarks:
General purpose bit flag
Bit 0: If set, indicates the file is encrypted
Bit 1-2 Only used for compression type 6 Imploding, and 8, 9 deflating
Imploding:
Bit 1 if set indicates an 8K sliding dictionary was used. If clear a 4k dictionary was used
Bit 2 if set indicates 3 Shannon-Fanno trees were used to encode the sliding dictionary, 2 otherwise
Deflating:
Bit 2 Bit 1
0 0 Normal compression was used
0 1 Maximum compression was used
1 0 Fast compression was used
1 1 Super fast compression was used
Bit 3: If set, the fields crc-32, compressed size and uncompressed size are were not able to be written during zip file creation The correct values are held in a data descriptor immediately following the compressed data.
Bit 4: Reserved for use by PKZIP for enhanced deflating
Bit 5: If set indicates the file contains compressed patch data
Bit 6: If set indicates strong encryption was used.
Bit 7-10: Unused or reserved
Bit 11: If set the name and comments for this entry are in unicode.
Bit 12-15: Unused or reserved

member.name: P:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.ZipEntry.ZipFileIndex
member.summary: Get/Set index of this entry in Zip file
member.remarks: This is only valid when the entry is part of a

member.summary: Get/set offset for use in central header

member.summary: Get/Set external file attributes as an integer. The values of this are operating system dependant see HostSystem for details

member.name: P:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.ZipEntry.VersionMadeBy
member.summary: Get the version made by for this entry or zero if unknown. The value / 10 indicates the major version number, and the value mod 10 is the minor version number

member.name: P:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.ZipEntry.IsDOSEntry
member.summary: Get a value indicating this entry is for a DOS/Windows system.

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.ZipEntry.HasDosAttributes(System.Int32)
member.summary: Test the external attributes for this to see if the external attributes are Dos based (including WINNT and variants) and match the values
member.param: The attributes to test.
member.returns: Returns true if the external attributes are known to be DOS/Windows based and have the same attributes set as the value passed.

member.name: P:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.ZipEntry.HostSystem
member.summary: Gets the compatability information for the external file attribute If the external file attributes are compatible with MS-DOS and can be read by PKZIP for DOS version 2.04g then this value will be zero. Otherwise the value will be non-zero and identify the host system on which the attributes are compatible.
member.remarks:
The values for this as defined in the Zip File format and by others are shown below. The values are somewhat misleading in some cases as they are not all used as shown. You should consult the relevant documentation to obtain up to date and correct information. The modified appnote by the infozip group is particularly helpful as it documents a lot of peculiarities. The document is however a little dated.
0 - MS-DOS and OS/2 (FAT / VFAT / FAT32 file systems)
1 - Amiga
2 - OpenVMS
3 - Unix
4 - VM/CMS
5 - Atari ST
6 - OS/2 HPFS
7 - Macintosh
8 - Z-System
9 - CP/M
10 - Windows NTFS
11 - MVS (OS/390 - Z/OS)
12 - VSE
13 - Acorn Risc
14 - VFAT
15 - Alternate MVS
16 - BeOS
17 - Tandem
18 - OS/400
19 - OS/X (Darwin)
99 - WinZip AES
remainder - unused

member.name: P:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.ZipEntry.Version
member.summary: Get minimum Zip feature version required to extract this entry
member.remarks:
Minimum features are defined as:
1.0 - Default value
1.1 - File is a volume label
2.0 - File is a folder/directory
2.0 - File is compressed using Deflate compression
2.0 - File is encrypted using traditional encryption
2.1 - File is compressed using Deflate64
2.5 - File is compressed using PKWARE DCL Implode
2.7 - File is a patch data set
4.5 - File uses Zip64 format extensions
4.6 - File is compressed using BZIP2 compression
5.0 - File is encrypted using DES
5.0 - File is encrypted using 3DES
5.0 - File is encrypted using original RC2 encryption
5.0 - File is encrypted using RC4 encryption
5.1 - File is encrypted using AES encryption
5.1 - File is encrypted using corrected RC2 encryption
5.1 - File is encrypted using corrected RC2-64 encryption
6.1 - File is encrypted using non-OAEP key wrapping
6.2 - Central directory encryption (not confirmed yet)
6.3 - File is compressed using LZMA
6.3 - File is compressed using PPMD+
6.3 - File is encrypted using Blowfish
6.3 - File is encrypted using Twofish

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.ZipEntry.CleanName(System.String)
member.summary: Cleans a name making it conform to Zip file conventions. Devices names ('c:\') and UNC share names ('\\server\share') are removed and forward slashes ('\') are converted to back slashes ('/'). Names are made relative by trimming leading slashes which is compatible with the ZIP naming convention.
member.param: The name to clean
member.returns: The 'cleaned' name.
member.remarks: The Zip name transform class is more flexible.

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.ExtendedUnixData.IsValidValue(System.DateTime)
member.summary: Test a value to see if is valid and can be represented here.
member.param: The value to test.
member.returns: Returns true if the value is valid and can be represented; false if not.
member.remarks: The standard Unix time is a signed integer data type, directly encoding the Unix time number, which is the number of seconds since 1970-01-01. Being 32 bits means the values here cover a range of about 136 years. The minimum representable time is 1901-12-13 20:45:52, and the maximum representable time is 2038-01-19 03:14:07.

member.name: T:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.ZipExtraData
member.summary: A class to handle the extra data field for Zip entries
member.remarks: Extra data contains 0 or more values each prefixed by a header tag and length. They contain zero or more bytes of actual data. The data is held internally using a copy on write strategy. This is more efficient but means that for extra data created by passing in data can have the values modified by the caller in some circumstances.

member.name: T:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.ZipFile
member.summary:
This class represents a Zip archive. You can ask for the contained entries, or get an input stream for a file entry. The entry is automatically decompressed.
You can also update the archive adding or deleting entries.
This class is thread safe for input: You can open input streams for arbitrary entries in different threads.
Author of the original java version : Jochen Hoenicke

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.ZipFile.UncompressedStream.Read(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Reads a sequence of bytes from the current stream and advances the position within the stream by the number of bytes read.
member.param: An array of bytes. When this method returns, the buffer contains the specified byte array with the values between offset and (offset + count - 1) replaced by the bytes read from the current source.
The zero-based byte offset in buffer at which to begin storing the data read from the current stream.
The maximum number of bytes to be read from the current stream.
member.returns: The total number of bytes read into the buffer. This can be less than the number of bytes requested if that many bytes are not currently available, or zero (0) if the end of the stream has been reached.
member.exception: The sum of offset and count is larger than the buffer length.
Methods were called after the stream was closed.
The stream does not support reading.

A value of type indicating the reference point used to obtain the new position.
member.returns: The new position within the current stream.
member.exception: The stream does not support seeking, such as if the stream is constructed from a pipe or console output.
Methods were called after the stream was closed.

member.name: T:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.ZipInputStream
member.summary:
This is an InflaterInputStream that reads the files baseInputStream an zip archive one after another. It has a special method to get the zip entry of the next file. The zip entry contains information about the file name size, compressed size, Crc, etc. It includes support for Stored and Deflated entries.
Author of the original java version : Jochen Hoenicke

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.ZipNameTransform.MakeValidName(System.String,System.Char)
member.summary: Force a name to be valid by replacing invalid characters with a fixed value
member.param: The name to force valid
The replacement character to use.
member.returns: Returns a valid name

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.ZipNameTransform.IsValidName(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Test a name to see if it is a valid name for a zip entry.
member.param: The name to test.
If true checking is relaxed about windows file names and absolute paths.
member.returns: Returns true if the name is a valid zip name; false otherwise.
member.remarks: Zip path names are actually in Unix format, and should only contain relative paths. This means that any path stored should not contain a drive or device letter, or a leading slash. All slashes should forward slashes '/'. An empty name is valid for a file where the input comes from standard input. A null name is not considered valid.

member.name: M:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.ZipNameTransform.IsValidName(System.String)
member.summary: Test a name to see if it is a valid name for a zip entry.
member.param: The name to test.
member.returns: Returns true if the name is a valid zip name; false otherwise.
member.remarks: Zip path names are actually in unix format, and should only contain relative paths if a path is present. This means that the path stored should not contain a drive or device letter, or a leading slash. All slashes should forward slashes '/'. An empty name is valid where the input comes from standard input. A null name is not considered valid.

member.name: T:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.ZipOutputStream
member.summary:
This is a DeflaterOutputStream that writes the files into a zip archive one after another. It has a special method to start a new zip entry. The zip entries contains information about the file name size, compressed size, CRC, etc.
It includes support for Stored and Deflated entries. This class is not thread safe.
Author of the original java version : Jochen Hoenicke

member.summary: Creates a new Zip output stream, writing a zip archive.

Size of the buffer to use.

member.name: P:ICSharpCode.SharpZipLib.Zip.ZipOutputStream.UseZip64
member.summary: Get / set a value indicating how Zip64 Extension usage is determined when adding entries.
